content.description: Tighten the edging shoes and have a clear head before leading this beauty.  We top-roped this route and it still rivals some of the best, often climbed routes in the McDowell's.  The first pitch is excellent on its own and would protect safely and easily with medium cams, felt 5.7.  Pitch two is more demanding and possibly frightening if you fall.  From the chain anchor, climb past bolt and upward to thin crack out right.  Crack will take small cams and nuts.  Exit crack to the left, cross the thin face and make it to a beautiful, solid crack that takes you to the summit.
content.protection: Medium and small gear, two bolts, chains at the 90 foot mark if you decide to break the route into two pitches (advisable).  Anchors at the summit.
content.location: Find the Main Wall, not hard since the trail walks right by it and you will see the start.  Pick your crack and head to the chain anchors at a nice belay stance.  You can see all of this from the trail.

content.description: P1: 5.10.  slick start up an easy angle that quickly gets more vertical. Follow a shallow finger tips crack to the first bolt approximately 20 feet up. From here the angle eases off again.  Clip a couple more bolts, past a horizontal hollow sounding crack, and then angle left to the anchors for Triple J.  Or clip a nice bolt, about paralell with the anchors and keep going up.  Crux is below first bolt to the second.    P2: 5.10- (from McDowell rock) climb crack on right side of face andthen over face and ramp to right somewhat around corner.  A crack leads to the top and anchor.  PG13 for the slick start and small gear protecting the crux.
content.protection: Small nuts.  Cams: singles from 0.1 - #3.  A pink tricam was bomber in the horizontal crack near the top of P1.   Draws and slings (4 bolts)
content.location: To the right of triple J.  Look for a thin, vertical, fingertips crack about 10 feet up.  Then look for the first bolt up 10 more feet and to the right of that crack.

content.description: Almost a face climb with a thin crack for protection on impeccable rock.  Some fairly blind placements of tiny cams will keep the leaders attention.  Choose your foot placements wisely...walk up the crack or keep one on the face.
content.protection: Small cams.  No anchor, walk off.
content.location: On the North side of main wall of Hog Heaven. Also, Directly above the routes George of the Jungle and Pissed Off.  There is a nice tree growing in beginning crack section just before horizontal crack leads to much thinner crack.

content.description: This route has a difficult start and a few more hard moves in the beginning.  Fairly short but strenuous and worth the time.  One can continue in the crack or climb the face straight up once you exit the thin start and locate a nice jam higher up.
content.protection: Thin gear up to #2 for the lead, otherwise easy to TR from the summit anchors.
content.location: This route is a few feet up from the route Chalk Bag.  Obvious thin crack with dirty start.  Bolted anchor at top.

content.description: The crux is moving over/around the roof at the second bolt.  Rock quality is great and the climb after the roof eases off and is enjoyable and safe.  A nice warmup for other routes in the area or as a stand alone climb.
content.protection: Two bolts below the roof, the old one is not inspiring for a committing move through the roof.  Nuts and medium cams protect the remainder of the route.
content.location: This will be one of the first routes encountered off the Hogs Heaven Trail and is just to the right (north) of the Main Wall.  You should be able to locate an original, rusty bolt right below the mini-roof.  There is a newer, cryptic bolt that can almost be clipped from the ground if one desires.     Walk off, climb to the Main Wall summit and rap off or rig another way to reach the base of the route.

climbs.name: John's Bag
climbs.fa: John Ficker, Jason Sands, John Mitchell

content.description:
A finger tips crack with an exciting exit under a small roof.  Climb awkward feeling moves to access crack and sew it up with the appropriate small gear.  At the roof, exit left underneath roof on good jams until you touch ground.

 According to Phoenix Rock, this route was originally a 5.8++.  Two pluses must equal a 10.
content.protection: Cams to #1, one stuck nut.  Walk off.
content.location: On the south side of the main wall of Hog Heaven.  Several feet to the left of Sand's Bag and Chalk Bag.  Look for stuck nut hanging out of crack.

content.description: Either start at the base of the large crack that is completely covered by hop-seed bushes or an obvious arete just to the right of the large crack.  Not wanting to mess with the shrubbery we began on the arete and it worked nicely.  Decent rock but watch for some large loose blocks within the first 35 feet (easily avoided), overall an easy scramble and nice warmup.
content.protection: Minimum gear needed but a few medium to large cams should cover the route.
content.location: Located to the left of Pissed Off and below a semi-alive hop-seed or oak-like tree.  Use the same descent information for the route Pissed Off.

content.description: A nice warmup route.  If there is a crux it will be encountered around the bushes near the start, otherwise fairly easy and straightforward.
content.protection: Single rack up to #3, no bolts except the anchor.
content.location: On the Main Wall and around the corner (south side), locate longest and obvious crack system that will take you all the way to the summit.  Some bushes down low pose no problems and good gear can be found the entire way.  Anchors at top.

content.description: This is the showcase wall of the area, with an east face that rises to nearly 200 feet (one of the longest faces in the McDowells). Original exploration and establishment of routes here was done by pioneer climbers John Ficker and Jason Sandidge, known for their solid climbing skills and mentally challenging routes. Recent addition of retrobolts to their established climbs is sort of an insult, given todays climbers have better (and more) gear and way better shoes.
